is essentially a veteran of the game at
this point with some of his oldest
mixtapes being 10 years old or more
which is like 30 in Chicago years the
violence and gang activity in the windy
city has been a Hot Topic and a huge
draw in the world of hip-hop for a while
now not just in terms of record sales
and up-and-coming artists but also
headlines social media firestorms and
changing artistic Aesthetics in numerous
rap scenes in the UK New York and Beyond
many artists who are integral to the
drill scene explosion in the early 2010s
have either moved on they're focusing
Less on music they've found a way to
escape or tragically they died this is
not a genre that historically inspires
longevity which is what makes Dirk such
an interesting case despite the numerous
beefs and brushes with the law he's been
in over the course of his career dude is
still standing and now dropping his
eighth full-length LP I have to give it
to Dirk because he's usually pretty open
about the way he's been impacted by the
violence he's either been exposed to or
enacted the loss of close friends and
family members the trauma I mean
emotional depth in any art form is of
course good but it's especially a breath
of fresh air in a sub-genre where a lot
of your competition is trying to seem as
invincible and as irrationally Cutthroat
as possible and Dirk gives us that depth
with moments like the opener where
Alicia Keys is moving through a spoken
word Spiel as if she's Dirk's therapist
and this session or album is a place
where he can be honest about his
feelings and vent there's obviously the
cover here where it's clearly a nod to
him healing from the various things he's
dealt with and experienced over the
years and and also who can forget the
lead single from this project All My
Life featuring J Cole which
instrumentally features touching pianos
a really awesome and inspiring kids
chorus the cut is anthemic and moving in
the best way possible there's a lot of
bars on this track featuring Dirk trying
to better himself despite everything
working against him the call feature on
the track is really impressive too it's
tight it's expressive it's witty he
leaves us off with bars about him
wishing to see his friends die of old
age which unfortunately is a luxury many
rappers are robbed of these days now a
record from someone of Dirk's stature
that deals in these types of messages
consistently could have been a classic
maybe even a game changer at the very
least the best album in his discography
but we really only get a few more whiffs
of his introspective side on a few more
Cuts in the first leg of the record be
it on pelicote or never again we then
hop into a generic trap Banger with put

from Chief wook on big dog and a

through that I was hoping this record

this until Dirk is really just back in
the trenches on these tracks whether
that be on you got them or before Fajr
which are both just loaded with

I'm not really surprised to hear him dip

about and don't get me wrong these

yeah unfortunately despite the fact that
